idiom: မျက်နှာကို မျက်နှာပြင်မှာ ထားပါ
literal_meaning: Put your face on the surface.
figurative_meaning: To maintain a good appearance or reputation.
example: In business, it's important to put your face on the surface and present yourself well.

idiom: လက်မောင်းထဲမှာ ရေခဲ
figurative_meaning: To have a hidden agenda or secret plans.
example: He seems friendly, but I suspect he has ice in the palm.

idiom: အိမ်ထောင်ဖက်ကို အချစ်ဖြင့် ကြိုးစားပါ
literal_meaning: Strive with love for your partner.
figurative_meaning: Work hard to maintain a loving relationship.
example: In marriage, you must always strive with love for your partner to keep the bond strong.

idiom: ကြိုးစားရင် ရတနာတွေ ရှာရမယ်
literal_meaning: If you strive, you will find treasures.
example: Remember, if you strive, you will find treasures in your career.

idiom: သစ်ပင်ကလေးတွေနဲ့ အလွတ်ပေးပါ
figurative_meaning: Support and nurture the younger generation.
example: It's important to give freely with young trees to ensure their growth and success.

figurative_meaning: To be cautious about what is directly in front of you.
example: Always look out for dangers; there are often fish in front of a fish's head.

idiom: လေပြေလျှင် လက်ကားမကောင်း
literal_meaning: When the wind blows, the hand is not good.
figurative_meaning: To be cautious during uncertain times.
example: In times of crisis, remember that when the wind blows, the hand is not good; be careful with your decisions.

idiom: အိမ်ထောင်ဖက်ကို အချစ်ဖြင့် ကြိုးစားပါ
literal_meaning: Strive with love for your partner.
figurative_meaning: Work hard to maintain a loving relationship.
example: In marriage, it's essential to strive with love for your partner to keep the bond strong.

idiom: အမြင်ကွဲပြားမှု
figurative_meaning: Understanding that everyone has different viewpoints.
example: In discussions, remember that အမြင်ကွဲပြားမှု can lead to better solutions if we listen to each other.
